segment.source: A tile is an app's representation on the Start menu.
segment.target: A tile is an app's representation on the Start menu.

segment.source: Every app has a tile.
segment.target: Every app has a tile.

segment.source: When you create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Microsoft Visual Studio, it includes a default tile that displays your app's name and logo.
segment.target: When you create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Microsoft Visual Studio, it includes a default tile that displays your app's name and logo.

segment.source: Tiles
segment.target: Tiles

segment.source: Tiles for UWP apps
segment.target: Tiles for UWP apps

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: A tile is an app's representation on the Start menu.
segment.target: A tile is an app's representation on the Start menu.

segment.source: Every app has a tile.
segment.target: Every app has a tile.

segment.source: When you create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Microsoft Visual Studio, it includes a default tile that displays your app's name and logo.
segment.target: When you create a new Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app project in Microsoft Visual Studio, it includes a default tile that displays your app's name and logo.

segment.source: Windows displays this tile when your app is first installed.
segment.target: Windows displays this tile when your app is first installed.

segment.source: After your app is installed, you can change your tile's content through notifications; for example, you can change the tile to communicate new information to the user, such as news headlines, or the subject of the most recent unread message.
segment.target: After your app is installed, you can change your tile's content through notifications; for example, you can change the tile to communicate new information to the user, such as news headlines, or the subject of the most recent unread message.

segment.source: Configure the default tile
segment.target: Configure the default tile

segment.source: When you create a new project in Visual Studio, it creates a simple default tile that displays your app's name and logo.
segment.target: When you create a new project in Visual Studio, it creates a simple default tile that displays your app's name and logo.

segment.source: There are a few items you should update:
segment.target: There are a few items you should update:

segment.source: DisplayName: Replace this value with the name you want to display on your tile.
segment.target: DisplayName: Replace this value with the name you want to display on your tile.

segment.source: ShortName: Because there is limited room for your display name to fit on tiles, we recommend that you to specify a ShortName as well, to make sure your app's name doesn’t get truncated.
segment.target: ShortName: Because there is limited room for your display name to fit on tiles, we recommend that you to specify a ShortName as well, to make sure your app's name doesn’t get truncated.

segment.source: Logo images:
segment.target: Logo images:

segment.source: You should replace these images with your own.
segment.target: You should replace these images with your own.

segment.source: You have the option of supplying images for different visual scales, but you are not required to supply them all.
segment.target: You have the option of supplying images for different visual scales, but you are not required to supply them all.

segment.source: To ensure that you app looks good on a range of devices, we recommend that you provide 100%, 200%, and 400% scale versions of each image.
segment.target: To ensure that you app looks good on a range of devices, we recommend that you provide 100%, 200%, and 400% scale versions of each image.

segment.source: Scaled images follow this naming convention:
segment.target: Scaled images follow this naming convention:

segment.source: image name.scale-scale factor.image file extension
segment.target: image name.scale-scale factor.image file extension

segment.source: For example: SmallLogo.scale-100.png
segment.target: For example: SmallLogo.scale-100.png

segment.source: When you refer to the image, you refer to it as image name.image file extension ("SmallLogo.png" in this example).
segment.target: When you refer to the image, you refer to it as image name.image file extension ("SmallLogo.png" in this example).

segment.source: The system will automatically select the appropriate scaled image for the device from the images you've provided.
segment.target: The system will automatically select the appropriate scaled image for the device from the images you've provided.

segment.source: You don't have to, but we highly recommend supplying logos for wide and large tile sizes so that the user can resize your app's tile to those sizes.
segment.target: You don't have to, but we highly recommend supplying logos for wide and large tile sizes so that the user can resize your app's tile to those sizes.

segment.source: To provide these additional images, you create a element and use the and attributes to specify the additional images:
segment.target: To provide these additional images, you create a element and use the and attributes to specify the additional images:

segment.source: Use notifications to customize your tile
segment.target: Use notifications to customize your tile

segment.source: After your app is installed, you can use notifications to customize your tile.
segment.target: After your app is installed, you can use notifications to customize your tile.

segment.source: You can do this the first time your app launches or in response to some event, such as a push notification.
segment.target: You can do this the first time your app launches or in response to some event, such as a push notification.

segment.source: Create an XML payload (in the form of an Windows.Data.Xml.Dom.XmlDocument) that describes the tile.
segment.target: Create an XML payload (in the form of an Windows.Data.Xml.Dom.XmlDocument) that describes the tile.

segment.source: Windows 10 introduces a new adaptive tile schema you can use.
segment.target: Windows 10 introduces a new adaptive tile schema you can use.

segment.source: For instructions, see Adaptive tiles.
segment.target: For instructions, see Adaptive tiles.

segment.source: For the schema, see the Adaptive tiles schema.
segment.target: For the schema, see the Adaptive tiles schema.

segment.source: You can use the Windows 8.1 tile templates to define your tile.
segment.target: You can use the Windows 8.1 tile templates to define your tile.

segment.source: For more info, see Creating tiles and badges (Windows 8.1).
segment.target: For more info, see Creating tiles and badges (Windows 8.1).

segment.source: Create a tile notification object and pass it the XmlDocument you created.
segment.target: Create a tile notification object and pass it the XmlDocument you created.

segment.source: There are several types of notification objects:
segment.target: There are several types of notification objects:

segment.source: A Windows.UI.NotificationsTileNotification object for updating the tile immediately.
segment.target: A Windows.UI.NotificationsTileNotification object for updating the tile immediately.

segment.source: A Windows.UI.Notifications.ScheduledTileNotification object for updating the tile at some point in the future.
segment.target: A Windows.UI.Notifications.ScheduledTileNotification object for updating the tile at some point in the future.

segment.source: Use the Windows.UI.Notifications.TileUpdateManager.CreateTileUpdaterForApplication to create a TileUpdater object.
segment.target: Use the Windows.UI.Notifications.TileUpdateManager.CreateTileUpdaterForApplication to create a TileUpdater object.

segment.source: Call the TileUpdater.Update method and pass it the tile notification object you created in step 2.
segment.target: Call the TileUpdater.Update method and pass it the tile notification object you created in step 2.
